an5.157:1.1.pli: “Pañcannaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalānaṃ kathā dukkathā puggale puggalaṃ upanidhāya.
an5.157:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it is inappropriate to speak to five individuals by comparing that individual with someone else.

an5.157:1.3.eng: It’s inappropriate to talk to an unfaithful person about faith.

an5.157:1.4.eng: It’s inappropriate to talk to an unethical person about ethics.

an5.157:1.5.eng: It’s inappropriate to talk to an unlearned person about learning.

an5.157:1.6.eng: It’s inappropriate to talk to a stingy person about generosity.

an5.157:1.7.eng: It’s inappropriate to talk to a witless person about wisdom.

an5.157:2.1.pli: Kasmā ca, bhikkhave, assaddhassa saddhākathā dukkathā?
an5.157:2.1.eng: And why is it inappropriate to talk to an unfaithful person about faith?

an5.157:2.2.pli: Assaddho, bhikkhave, saddhākathāya kacchamānāya abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patitthīyati kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an5.157:2.2.eng: When an unfaithful person is spoken to about faith they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an5.157:2.4.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, saddhāsampadaṃ attani na samanupassati, na ca labhati tatonidānaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ.
an5.157:2.4.eng: Not seeing that faith in themselves, they don’t get the rapture and joy that faith brings.

an5.157:2.5.eng: That’s why it’s inappropriate to talk to an unfaithful person about faith.

an5.157:3.1.pli: Kasmā ca, bhikkhave, dussīlassa sīlakathā dukkathā?
an5.157:3.1.eng: And why is it inappropriate to talk to an unethical person about ethics?

an5.157:3.2.pli: Dussīlo, bhikkhave, sīlakathāya kacchamānāya abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patitthīyati kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an5.157:3.2.eng: When an unethical person is spoken to about ethics they lose their temper …

an5.157:3.4.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, sīlasampadaṃ attani na samanupassati na ca labhati tatonidānaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ.
an5.157:3.4.eng: Not seeing that ethical conduct in themselves, they don’t get the rapture and joy that ethical conduct brings.

an5.157:3.5.eng: That’s why it’s inappropriate to talk to an unethical person about ethics.

an5.157:4.1.pli: Kasmā ca, bhikkhave, appassutassa bāhusaccakathā dukkathā?
an5.157:4.1.eng: And why is it inappropriate to talk to an unlearned person about learning?

an5.157:4.2.pli: Appassuto, bhikkhave, bāhusaccakathāya kacchamānāya abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patitthīyati kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an5.157:4.2.eng: When an unlearned person is spoken to about learning they lose their temper …

an5.157:4.4.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, sutasampadaṃ attani na samanupassati, na ca labhati tatonidānaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ.
an5.157:4.4.eng: Not seeing that learning in themselves, they don’t get the rapture and joy that learning brings.

an5.157:4.5.eng: That’s why it’s inappropriate to talk to an unlearned person about learning.

an5.157:5.1.pli: Kasmā ca, bhikkhave, maccharissa cāgakathā dukkathā?
an5.157:5.1.eng: And why is it inappropriate to talk to a stingy person about generosity?

an5.157:5.2.pli: Maccharī, bhikkhave, cāgakathāya kacchamānāya abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patitthīyati kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an5.157:5.2.eng: When a stingy person is spoken to about generosity they lose their temper …

an5.157:5.4.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, cāgasampadaṃ attani na samanupassati na ca labhati tatonidānaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ.
an5.157:5.4.eng: Not seeing that generosity in themselves, they don’t get the rapture and joy that generosity brings.

an5.157:5.5.eng: That’s why it’s inappropriate to talk to a stingy person about generosity.

an5.157:6.1.pli: Kasmā ca, bhikkhave, duppaññassa paññākathā dukkathā?
an5.157:6.1.eng: And why is it inappropriate to talk to a witless person about wisdom?

an5.157:6.2.pli: Duppañño, bhikkhave, paññākathāya kacchamānāya abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patitthīyati kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an5.157:6.2.eng: When a witless person is spoken to about wisdom they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an5.157:6.4.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, paññāsampadaṃ attani na samanupassati, na ca labhati tatonidānaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ.
an5.157:6.4.eng: Not seeing that wisdom in themselves, they don’t get the rapture and joy that wisdom brings.

an5.157:6.5.eng: That’s why it’s inappropriate to talk to a witless person about wisdom.

an5.157:6.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ puggalānaṃ kathā dukkathā puggale puggalaṃ upanidhāya.
an5.157:6.6.eng: It is inappropriate to speak to these five individuals by comparing that individual with someone else.

an5.157:7.1.pli: Pañcannaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalānaṃ kathā sukathā puggale puggalaṃ upanidhāya.
an5.157:7.1.eng: It is appropriate to speak to five individuals by comparing that individual with someone else.

an5.157:7.3.eng: It’s appropriate to talk to a faithful person about faith.

an5.157:7.4.eng: It’s appropriate to talk to an ethical person about ethical conduct.

an5.157:7.5.eng: It’s appropriate to talk to a learned person about learning.

an5.157:7.6.eng: It’s appropriate to talk to a generous person about generosity.

an5.157:7.7.eng: It’s appropriate to talk to a wise person about wisdom.

an5.157:8.1.pli: Kasmā ca, bhikkhave, saddhassa saddhākathā sukathā?
an5.157:8.1.eng: And why is it appropriate to talk to a faithful person about faith?

an5.157:8.2.pli: Saddho, bhikkhave, saddhākathāya kacchamānāya nābhisajjati na kuppati na byāpajjati na patitthīyati na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an5.157:8.2.eng: When a faithful person is spoken to about faith they don’t lose their temper, they don’t get annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an5.157:8.4.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, saddhāsampadaṃ attani samanupassati labhati ca tatonidānaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ.
an5.157:8.4.eng: Seeing that faith in themselves, they get the rapture and joy that faith brings.

an5.157:8.5.eng: That’s why it’s appropriate to talk to a faithful person about faith.

an5.157:9.1.pli: Kasmā ca, bhikkhave, sīlavato sīlakathā sukathā?
an5.157:9.1.eng: And why is it appropriate to talk to an ethical person about ethical conduct?

an5.157:9.2.pli: Sīlavā, bhikkhave, sīlakathāya kacchamānāya nābhisajjati na kuppati na byāpajjati na patitthīyati na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an5.157:9.2.eng: When an ethical person is spoken to about ethical conduct they don’t lose their temper …

an5.157:9.4.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, sīlasampadaṃ attani samanupassati, labhati ca tatonidānaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ.
an5.157:9.4.eng: Seeing that ethical conduct in themselves, they get the rapture and joy that ethical conduct brings.

an5.157:9.5.eng: That’s why it’s appropriate to talk to an ethical person about ethical conduct.

an5.157:10.1.pli: Kasmā ca, bhikkhave, bahussutassa bāhusaccakathā sukathā?
an5.157:10.1.eng: And why is it appropriate to talk to a learned person about learning?

an5.157:10.2.pli: Bahussuto, bhikkhave, bāhusaccakathāya kacchamānāya nābhisajjati na kuppati na byāpajjati na patitthīyati na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an5.157:10.2.eng: When a learned person is spoken to about learning they don’t lose their temper …

an5.157:10.4.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, sutasampadaṃ attani samanupassati, labhati ca tatonidānaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ.
an5.157:10.4.eng: Seeing that learning in themselves, they get the rapture and joy that learning brings.

an5.157:10.5.eng: That’s why it’s appropriate to talk to a learned person about learning.

an5.157:11.1.pli: Kasmā ca, bhikkhave, cāgavato cāgakathā sukathā?
an5.157:11.1.eng: And why is it appropriate to talk to a generous person about generosity?

an5.157:11.2.pli: Cāgavā, bhikkhave, cāgakathāya kacchamānāya nābhisajjati na kuppati na byāpajjati na patitthīyati na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an5.157:11.2.eng: When a generous person is spoken to about generosity they don’t lose their temper …

an5.157:11.4.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, cāgasampadaṃ attani samanupassati, labhati ca tatonidānaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ.
an5.157:11.4.eng: Seeing that generosity in themselves, they get the rapture and joy that generosity brings.

an5.157:11.5.eng: That’s why it’s appropriate to talk to a generous person about generosity.

an5.157:12.1.pli: Kasmā ca, bhikkhave, paññavato paññākathā sukathā?
an5.157:12.1.eng: And why is it appropriate to talk to a wise person about wisdom?

an5.157:12.2.pli: Paññavā, bhikkhave, paññākathāya kacchamānāya nābhisajjati na kuppati na byāpajjati na patitthīyati na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an5.157:12.2.eng: When a wise person is spoken to about wisdom they don’t lose their temper, they don’t get annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an5.157:12.4.pli: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, paññāsampadaṃ attani samanupassati labhati ca tatonidānaṃ pītipāmojjaṃ.
an5.157:12.4.eng: Seeing that wisdom in themselves, they get the rapture and joy that wisdom brings.

an5.157:12.5.eng: That’s why it’s appropriate to talk to a wise person about wisdom.

an5.157:12.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ puggalānaṃ kathā sukathā puggale puggalaṃ upanidhāyā”ti.
an5.157:12.6.eng: It is appropriate to speak to these five individuals by comparing that individual with someone else.”

an5.158:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sārajjaṃ okkanto hoti.
an5.158:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is overcome by timidity.

an5.158:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu assaddho hoti, dussīlo hoti, appassuto hoti, kusīto hoti, duppañño hoti.
an5.158:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is faithless, unethical, with little learning, lazy, and witless.

an5.158:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sārajjaṃ okkanto hoti.
an5.158:1.4.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is overcome by timidity.

an5.158:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu visārado hoti.
an5.158:2.1.eng: A mendicant with five qualities is self-assured.

an5.158:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddho hoti, sīlavā hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, paññavā hoti.
an5.158:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is faithful, ethical, learned, energetic, and wise.

an5.158:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu visārado hotī”ti.
an5.158:2.4.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is self-assured.”

an5.159:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
an5.159:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

an5.159:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā udāyī mahatiyā gihiparisāya parivuto dhammaṃ desento nisinno hoti.
an5.159:1.3.eng: Now, at that time Venerable Udāyī was sitting teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly of laypeople.

an5.159:1.4.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ mahatiyā gihiparisāya parivutaṃ dhammaṃ desentaṃ nisinnaṃ.

an5.159:1.5.pli: Disvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.159:1.5.eng: went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an5.159:1.6.pli: “āyasmā, bhante, udāyī mahatiyā gihiparisāya parivuto dhammaṃ desetī”ti.
an5.159:1.6.eng: “Sir, Venerable Udāyī is teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly of laypeople.”

an5.159:2.1.pli: “Na kho, ānanda, sukaraṃ paresaṃ dhammaṃ desetuṃ.
an5.159:2.1.eng: “Ānanda, it’s not easy to teach Dhamma to others.

an5.159:2.2.pli: Paresaṃ, ānanda, dhammaṃ desentena pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ upaṭṭhāpetvā paresaṃ dhammo desetabbo.
an5.159:2.2.eng: You should establish five things in yourself before teaching Dhamma to others.

an5.159:2.4.eng: You should teach Dhamma to others thinking: ‘I will teach step by step.’ …

an5.159:2.6.pli: ‘anuddayataṃ paṭicca kathaṃ kathessāmī’ti paresaṃ dhammo desetabbo;

an5.159:2.7.pli: ‘na āmisantaro kathaṃ kathessāmī’ti paresaṃ dhammo desetabbo;
an5.159:2.7.eng: ‘I will not teach while secretly hoping to profit.’ …

an5.159:2.8.pli: ‘attānañca parañca anupahacca kathaṃ kathessāmī’ti paresaṃ dhammo desetabbo.
an5.159:2.8.eng: ‘I will teach without damaging myself or others.’

an5.159:2.9.pli: Na kho, ānanda, sukaraṃ paresaṃ dhammaṃ desetuṃ.
an5.159:2.9.eng: It’s not easy to teach Dhamma to others.

an5.159:2.10.pli: Paresaṃ, ānanda, dhammaṃ desentena ime pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ upaṭṭhāpetvā paresaṃ dhammo desetabbo”ti.
an5.159:2.10.eng: You should establish these five things in yourself before teaching Dhamma to others.”

an5.16:1.3.eng: The powers of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an5.16:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ balānaṃ etaṃ aggaṃ etaṃ saṅgāhikaṃ etaṃ saṅghātaniyaṃ, yadidaṃ paññābalaṃ.
an5.16:1.5.eng: Of these five powers, the power of wisdom is the chief. It holds and binds everything together.

an5.16:1.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kūṭāgārassa etaṃ aggaṃ etaṃ saṅgāhikaṃ etaṃ saṅghātaniyaṃ, yadidaṃ kūṭaṃ.
an5.16:1.6.eng: It’s like a bungalow. The roof-peak is the chief point, which holds and binds everything together.

an5.16:1.7.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, imesaṃ pañcannaṃ balānaṃ etaṃ aggaṃ etaṃ saṅgāhikaṃ etaṃ saṅghātaniyaṃ, yadidaṃ paññābalan”ti.
an5.16:1.7.eng: In the same way, of these five powers, the power of wisdom is the chief. It holds and binds everything together.”

an5.160:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five things are hard to get rid of once they’ve arisen.

an5.160:1.3.pli: Uppanno rāgo duppaṭivinodayo, uppanno doso duppaṭivinodayo, uppanno moho duppaṭivinodayo, uppannaṃ paṭibhānaṃ duppaṭivinodayaṃ, uppannaṃ gamikacittaṃ duppaṭivinodayaṃ.
an5.160:1.3.eng: Greed, hate, delusion, the feeling of being inspired to speak out, and thoughts of traveling.

an5.160:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca uppannā duppaṭivinodayā”ti.
an5.160:1.4.eng: These five things are hard to get rid of once they’ve arisen.”

an5.161:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, āghātapaṭivinayā yattha bhikkhuno uppanno āghāto sabbaso paṭivinetabbo.
an5.161:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant should use these five ways to completely get rid of resentment when it has arisen toward anyone.

an5.161:1.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, puggale āghāto jāyetha, mettā tasmiṃ puggale bhāvetabbā;
an5.161:1.3.eng: You should develop love for an individual you resent.

an5.161:1.4.eng: That’s how to get rid of resentment for that individual.

an5.161:1.5.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, puggale āghāto jāyetha, karuṇā tasmiṃ puggale bhāvetabbā;
an5.161:1.5.eng: You should develop compassion for an individual you resent. …

an5.161:1.7.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, puggale āghāto jāyetha, upekkhā tasmiṃ puggale bhāvetabbā;
an5.161:1.7.eng: You should develop equanimity for an individual you resent. …

an5.161:1.9.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, puggale āghāto jāyetha, asatiamanasikāro tasmiṃ puggale āpajjitabbo;
an5.161:1.9.eng: You should disregard an individual you resent, paying no attention to them. …

an5.161:1.11.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, puggale āghāto jāyetha, kammassakatā tasmiṃ puggale adhiṭṭhātabbā:
an5.161:1.11.eng: You should focus on the ownership of deeds regarding that individual:

an5.161:1.12.eng: ‘This venerable is the owner of their deeds and heir to their deeds. Deeds are their womb, their relative, and their refuge.

an5.161:1.13.pli: yaṃ kammaṃ karissati kalyāṇaṃ vā pāpakaṃ vā tassa dāyādo bhavissatī’ti;
an5.161:1.13.eng: They shall be the heir of whatever deeds they do, whether good or bad.’

an5.161:1.14.eng: That’s how to get rid of resentment for that individual.

an5.161:1.15.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca āghātapaṭivinayā, yattha bhikkhuno uppanno āghāto sabbaso paṭivinetabbo”ti.
an5.161:1.15.eng: A mendicant should use these five ways to completely get rid of resentment when it has arisen toward anyone.”

an5.162:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
an5.162:1.1.eng: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the mendicants:

an5.162:1.3.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

an5.162:2.1.pli: “Pañcime, āvuso, āghātapaṭivinayā yattha bhikkhuno uppanno āghāto sabbaso paṭivinetabbo.
an5.162:2.1.eng: “Reverends, a mendicant should use these five ways to completely get rid of resentment when it has arisen toward anyone.

an5.162:2.3.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco puggalo aparisuddhakāyasamācāro hoti parisuddhavacīsamācāro;
an5.162:2.3.eng: In the case of an individual whose behavior by way of body is impure, but whose behavior by way of speech is pure,

an5.162:2.4.eng: you should get rid of resentment for that kind of individual.

an5.162:2.5.pli: Idha panāvuso, ekacco puggalo aparisuddhavacīsamācāro hoti parisuddhakāyasamācāro;
an5.162:2.5.eng: In the case of an individual whose behavior by way of speech is impure, but whose behavior by way of body is pure, …

an5.162:2.7.pli: Idha panāvuso, ekacco puggalo aparisuddhakāyasamācāro hoti aparisuddhavacīsamācāro, labhati ca kālena kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ;
an5.162:2.7.eng: In the case of an individual whose behavior by way of body and speech is impure, but who gets an openness and clarity of heart from time to time, …

an5.162:2.9.pli: Idha panāvuso, ekacco puggalo aparisuddhakāyasamācāro hoti aparisuddhavacīsamācāro, na ca labhati kālena kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ;
an5.162:2.9.eng: In the case of an individual whose behavior by way of body and speech is impure, and who doesn’t get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time, …

an5.162:2.11.pli: Idha panāvuso, ekacco puggalo parisuddhakāyasamācāro parisuddhavacīsamācāro, labhati ca kālena vā kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ;
an5.162:2.11.eng: In the case of an individual whose behavior by way of body and speech is pure, and who gets an openness and clarity of heart from time to time,

an5.162:2.12.eng: you should get rid of resentment for that kind of individual.

an5.162:3.1.pli: Tatrāvuso, yvāyaṃ puggalo aparisuddhakāyasamācāro parisuddhavacīsamācāro, kathaṃ tasmiṃ puggale āghāto paṭivinetabbo?
an5.162:3.1.eng: How should you get rid of resentment for an individual whose behavior by way of body is impure, but whose behavior by way of speech is pure?

an5.162:3.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, bhikkhu paṃsukūliko rathiyāya nantakaṃ disvā vāmena pādena niggaṇhitvā dakkhiṇena pādena pattharitvā, yo tattha sāro taṃ paripātetvā ādāya pakkameyya;
an5.162:3.2.eng: Suppose a mendicant wearing rag robes sees a rag by the side of the road. They’d hold it down with the left foot, spread it out with the right foot, tear out what was intact, and take it away with them.

an5.162:3.3.pli: evamevaṃ khvāvuso, yvāyaṃ puggalo aparisuddhakāyasamācāro parisuddhavacīsamācāro, yāssa aparisuddhakāyasamācāratā na sāssa tasmiṃ samaye manasi kātabbā, yā ca khvassa parisuddhavacīsamācāratā sāssa tasmiṃ samaye manasi kātabbā.
an5.162:3.3.eng: In the same way, at that time you should ignore that individual’s impure behavior by way of body and focus on their pure behavior by way of speech.

an5.162:3.4.eng: That’s how to get rid of resentment for that individual.

an5.162:4.1.pli: Tatrāvuso, yvāyaṃ puggalo aparisuddhavacīsamācāro parisuddhakāyasamācāro, kathaṃ tasmiṃ puggale āghāto paṭivinetabbo?
an5.162:4.1.eng: How should you get rid of resentment for an individual whose behavior by way of speech is impure, but whose behavior by way of body is pure?

an5.162:4.2.eng: Suppose there was a lotus pond covered with moss and aquatic plants.

an5.162:4.3.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito.
an5.162:4.3.eng: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched.

an5.162:4.4.pli: So taṃ pokkharaṇiṃ ogāhetvā ubhohi hatthehi iticiti ca sevālapaṇakaṃ apaviyūhitvā añjalinā pivitvā pakkameyya.
an5.162:4.4.eng: They’d plunge into the lotus pond, sweep apart the moss and aquatic plants, drink from their cupped hands, and be on their way.

an5.162:4.5.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, yvāyaṃ puggalo aparisuddhavacīsamācāro parisuddhakāyasamācāro, yāssa aparisuddhavacīsamācāratā na sāssa tasmiṃ samaye manasi kātabbā, yā ca khvassa parisuddhakāyasamācāratā sāssa tasmiṃ samaye manasi kātabbā.
an5.162:4.5.eng: In the same way, at that time you should ignore that individual’s impure behavior by way of speech and focus on their pure behavior by way of body.

an5.162:4.6.eng: That’s how to get rid of resentment for that individual.

an5.162:5.1.pli: Tatrāvuso, yvāyaṃ puggalo aparisuddhakāyasamācāro aparisuddhavacīsamācāro labhati ca kālena kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ, kathaṃ tasmiṃ puggale āghāto paṭivinetabbo?
an5.162:5.1.eng: How should you get rid of resentment for an individual whose behavior by way of body and speech is impure, but who gets an openness and clarity of heart from time to time?

an5.162:5.2.eng: Suppose there was a little water in a cow’s hoofprint.

an5.162:5.3.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito.
an5.162:5.3.eng: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched.

an5.162:5.5.eng: ‘This little bit of water is in a cow’s hoofprint.

an5.162:5.6.pli: Sacāhaṃ añjalinā vā pivissāmi bhājanena vā khobhessāmipi taṃ loḷessāmipi taṃ apeyyampi taṃ karissāmi.
an5.162:5.6.eng: If I drink it with my cupped hands or a bowl, I’ll stir it and disturb it, making it undrinkable.

an5.162:5.7.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ catukkuṇḍiko nipatitvā gopītakaṃ pivitvā pakkameyyan’ti.
an5.162:5.7.eng: Why don’t I get down on all fours and drink it up like a cow, then be on my way?’

an5.162:5.8.pli: So catukkuṇḍiko nipatitvā gopītakaṃ pivitvā pakkameyya.

an5.162:5.9.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, yvāyaṃ puggalo aparisuddhakāyasamācāro aparisuddhavacīsamācāro labhati ca kālena kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ, yāssa aparisuddhakāyasamācāratā na sāssa tasmiṃ samaye manasi kātabbā;
an5.162:5.9.eng: In the same way, at that time you should ignore that individual’s impure behavior by way of speech and body,

an5.162:5.10.pli: yāpissa aparisuddhavacīsamācāratā na sāpissa tasmiṃ samaye manasi kātabbā.

an5.162:5.11.pli: Yañca kho so labhati kālena kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ, tamevassa tasmiṃ samaye manasi kātabbaṃ.
an5.162:5.11.eng: and focus on the fact that they get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time.

an5.162:5.12.eng: That’s how to get rid of resentment for that individual.

an5.162:6.1.pli: Tatrāvuso, yvāyaṃ puggalo aparisuddhakāyasamācāro aparisuddhavacīsamācāro na ca labhati kālena kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ, kathaṃ tasmiṃ puggale āghāto paṭivinetabbo?
an5.162:6.1.eng: How should you get rid of resentment for an individual whose behavior by way of body and speech is impure, and who doesn’t get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time?

an5.162:6.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, puriso ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno addhānamaggappaṭipanno.
an5.162:6.2.eng: Suppose a person was traveling along a road, and they were sick, suffering, gravely ill.

an5.162:6.3.pli: Tassa puratopissa dūre gāmo pacchatopissa dūre gāmo.
an5.162:6.3.eng: And it was a long way to a village, whether ahead or behind.

an5.162:6.4.pli: So na labheyya sappāyāni bhojanāni, na labheyya sappāyāni bhesajjāni, na labheyya patirūpaṃ upaṭṭhākaṃ, na labheyya gāmantanāyakaṃ.
an5.162:6.4.eng: And they didn’t have any suitable food or medicine, or a competent carer, or someone to bring them within a village.

an5.162:6.5.eng: Another person traveling along the road might see them,

an5.162:6.6.pli: So tasmiṃ purise kāruññaṃyeva upaṭṭhāpeyya, anuddayaṃyeva upaṭṭhāpeyya, anukampaṃyeva upaṭṭhāpeyya:
an5.162:6.6.eng: and think of them with nothing but sympathy, kindness, and sympathy:

an5.162:6.7.pli: ‘aho vatāyaṃ puriso labheyya sappāyāni bhojanāni, labheyya sappāyāni bhesajjāni, labheyya patirūpaṃ upaṭṭhākaṃ, labheyya gāmantanāyakaṃ.
an5.162:6.7.eng: ‘Oh, may this person get suitable food or medicine, or a competent carer, or someone to bring them within a village.

an5.162:6.9.eng: So that they don’t come to ruin right here.’

an5.162:6.10.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, yvāyaṃ puggalo aparisuddhakāyasamācāro aparisuddhavacīsamācāro na ca labhati kālena kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ, evarūpepi, āvuso, puggale kāruññaṃyeva upaṭṭhāpetabbaṃ anuddayāyeva upaṭṭhāpetabbā anukampāyeva upaṭṭhāpetabbā:
an5.162:6.10.eng: In the same way, at that time you should ignore that individual’s impure behavior by way of speech and body, and the fact that they don’t get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time, and think of them with nothing but compassion, kindness, and sympathy:

an5.162:6.11.pli: ‘aho vata ayamāyasmā kāyaduccaritaṃ pahāya kāyasucaritaṃ bhāveyya, vacīduccaritaṃ pahāya vacīsucaritaṃ bhāveyya, manoduccaritaṃ pahāya manosucaritaṃ bhāveyya.
an5.162:6.11.eng: ‘Oh, may this venerable give up bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and develop good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an5.162:6.13.pli: Māyaṃ āyasmā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjī’ti.
an5.162:6.13.eng: So that, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re not reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’

an5.162:6.14.eng: That’s how to get rid of resentment for that individual.

an5.162:7.1.pli: Tatrāvuso, yvāyaṃ puggalo parisuddhakāyasamācāro parisuddhavacīsamācāro labhati ca kālena kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ, kathaṃ tasmiṃ puggale āghāto paṭivinetabbo?
an5.162:7.1.eng: How should you get rid of resentment for an individual whose behavior by way of body and speech is pure, and who gets an openness and clarity of heart from time to time?

an5.162:7.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, pokkharaṇī acchodakā sātodakā sītodakā setakā supatitthā ramaṇīyā nānārukkhehi sañchannā.
an5.162:7.2.eng: Suppose there was a lotus pond with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful, and shaded by many trees.

an5.162:7.3.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya ghammābhitatto ghammapareto kilanto tasito pipāsito.
an5.162:7.3.eng: Then along comes a person struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched.

an5.162:7.4.pli: So taṃ pokkharaṇiṃ ogāhetvā nhātvā ca pivitvā ca paccuttaritvā tattheva rukkhacchāyāya nisīdeyya vā nipajjeyya vā.
an5.162:7.4.eng: They’d plunge into the lotus pond to bathe and drink. And after emerging they’d sit or lie down right there in the shade of the trees.

an5.162:8.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, yvāyaṃ puggalo parisuddhakāyasamācāro parisuddhavacīsamācāro labhati ca kālena kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ, yāpissa parisuddhakāyasamācāratā sāpissa tasmiṃ samaye manasi kātabbā;
an5.162:8.1.eng: In the same way, at that time you should focus on that individual’s pure behavior by way of body and speech, and on the fact that they get an openness and clarity of heart from time to time.

an5.162:8.2.pli: yāpissa parisuddhavacīsamācāratā sāpissa tasmiṃ samaye manasi kātabbā;

an5.162:8.3.pli: yampi labhati kālena kālaṃ cetaso vivaraṃ cetaso pasādaṃ, tampissa tasmiṃ samaye manasi kātabbaṃ.

an5.162:8.4.eng: That’s how to get rid of resentment for that individual.

an5.162:8.5.pli: Samantapāsādikaṃ, āvuso, puggalaṃ āgamma cittaṃ pasīdati.
an5.162:8.5.eng: Relying on an individual who is impressive all around, the mind becomes confident.

an5.162:9.1.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, pañca āghātapaṭivinayā, yattha bhikkhuno uppanno āghāto sabbaso paṭivinetabbo”ti.
an5.162:9.1.eng: A mendicant should use these five ways to completely get rid of resentment when it has arisen toward anyone.”

an5.163:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
an5.163:1.1.eng: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the mendicants:

an5.163:1.3.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

an5.163:2.1.pli: “Pañcahāvuso, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ sākaccho sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an5.163:2.1.eng: “A mendicant with five qualities is fit to hold a discussion with their spiritual companions.

an5.163:2.3.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu attanā ca sīlasampanno hoti, sīlasampadākathāya ca āgataṃ pañhaṃ byākattā hoti;
an5.163:2.3.eng: A mendicant is personally accomplished in ethics, and answers questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in ethics.

an5.163:2.4.pli: attanā ca samādhisampanno hoti, samādhisampadākathāya ca āgataṃ pañhaṃ byākattā hoti;

an5.163:2.5.pli: attanā ca paññāsampanno hoti, paññāsampadākathāya ca āgataṃ pañhaṃ byākattā hoti;

an5.163:2.6.pli: attanā ca vimuttisampanno hoti, vimuttisampadākathāya ca āgataṃ pañhaṃ byākattā hoti;

an5.163:2.7.pli: attanā ca vimuttiñāṇadassanasampanno hoti, vimuttiñāṇadassanasampadākathāya ca āgataṃ pañhaṃ byākattā hoti.
an5.163:2.7.eng: They’re personally accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.163:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, āvuso, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ sākaccho sabrahmacārīnan”ti.
an5.163:2.8.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is fit to hold a discussion with their spiritual companions.”

an5.164:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi …pe…
an5.164:1.1.eng: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the mendicants:

an5.164:1.2.pli: pañcahi, āvuso, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃsājīvo sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an5.164:1.2.eng: “A mendicant with five qualities is fit to share their life with their spiritual companions.

an5.164:1.4.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu attanā ca sīlasampanno hoti, sīlasampadākathāya ca āgataṃ pañhaṃ byākattā hoti;
an5.164:1.4.eng: A mendicant is personally accomplished in ethics, and answers questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in ethics.

an5.164:1.5.pli: attanā ca samādhisampanno hoti, samādhisampadākathāya ca āgataṃ pañhaṃ byākattā hoti;

an5.164:1.6.pli: attanā ca paññāsampanno hoti, paññāsampadākathāya ca āgataṃ pañhaṃ byākattā hoti;

an5.164:1.7.pli: attanā ca vimuttisampanno hoti, vimuttisampadākathāya ca āgataṃ pañhaṃ byākattā hoti;

an5.164:1.8.pli: attanā ca vimuttiñāṇadassanasampanno hoti, vimuttiñāṇadassanasampadākathāya ca āgataṃ pañhaṃ byākattā hoti.
an5.164:1.8.eng: They’re personally accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom, and they answer questions that come up when discussing accomplishment in the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.164:1.9.pli: Imehi kho, āvuso, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃsājīvo sabrahmacārīnan”ti.
an5.164:1.9.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is fit to share their life with their spiritual companions.”

an5.165:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi …pe… “yo hi koci, āvuso, paraṃ pañhaṃ pucchati, sabbo so pañcahi ṭhānehi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena.
an5.165:1.1.eng: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the mendicants: … “Whoever asks a question of another, does so for one or other of these five reasons.

an5.165:1.3.pli: Mandattā momūhattā paraṃ pañhaṃ pucchati, pāpiccho icchāpakato paraṃ pañhaṃ pucchati, paribhavaṃ paraṃ pañhaṃ pucchati, aññātukāmo paraṃ pañhaṃ pucchati, atha vā panevaṃcitto paraṃ pañhaṃ pucchati:
an5.165:1.3.eng: Someone asks a question of another from stupidity and folly. Or they ask from corrupt wishes, being of wishful temperament. Or they ask in order to disparage. Or they ask wanting to understand. Or they ask with the thought,

an5.165:1.4.pli: ‘sace me pañhaṃ puṭṭho sammadeva byākarissati iccetaṃ kusalaṃ, no ce me pañhaṃ puṭṭho sammadeva byākarissati ahamassa sammadeva byākarissāmī’ti.
an5.165:1.4.eng: ‘If they correctly answer the question I ask it’s good. If not, I’ll correctly answer it for them.’

an5.165:1.5.pli: Yo hi koci, āvuso, paraṃ pañhaṃ pucchati, sabbo so imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena.
an5.165:1.5.eng: Whoever asks a question of another, does so for one or other of these five reasons.

an5.165:1.6.pli: Ahaṃ kho panāvuso, evaṃcitto paraṃ pañhaṃ pucchāmi:
an5.165:1.6.eng: As for myself, I ask with the thought,

an5.165:1.7.pli: ‘sace me pañhaṃ puṭṭho sammadeva byākarissati iccetaṃ kusalaṃ, no ce me pañhaṃ puṭṭho sammadeva byākarissati, ahamassa sammadeva byākarissāmī’”ti.
an5.165:1.7.eng: ‘If they correctly answer the question I ask it’s good. If not, I’ll correctly answer it for them.’”
